46:59 Caption: Well, it hasn't been the most exciting game in the world but there has been some nice football on display. We hope that the second period will bring more action. Barcelona have arguably been the better of the two sides in the first half. The home team's main weapon is fast counter-attacks, while the away side attempts to hold onto the ball for as long as possible.

47:59 Caption: Today's game was very poor. There weren't many thrilling moments. Barcelona had more of the game and were superior. Their manager will certainly be the happier of the two managers. The hosts tried to catch the opposition off guard and hit them on the break. The visiting side kept the ball at their feet and the main intention was to produce that final killer pass.
    

    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
In an anticipated clash between two La Liga giants, Atletico Madrid hosted Barcelona at the Wanda Metropolitano Stadium. The game delivered a tightly contested affair where Barcelona emerged victorious with a 2-1 win. Here’s an in-depth look at the minute-by-minute unfolding of the match.

The game kicked off as the referee blew his whistle at exactly 00:00, with Barcelona getting proceedings underway. The initial exchanges were cautious, with both teams trying to feel each other out. Early on, the ball went out of play (00:15) leading to a throw-in by Atletico Madrid (00:30). Atletico had an early chance at goal with a shot off target (00:51), but it only just signaled their intent rather than causing any real trouble.

Barcelona immediately looked to clear their lines (01:02), but the game’s physicality started showing early. At 01:50, Atletico Madrid committed a foul, handing Barcelona an indirect free-kick (02:03). The pace was relentless, with the ball frequently being turned over and going out of play multiple times in the opening minutes.

Jordi Alba made a promising offensive foray for Barcelona, sending a cross into the box around the 11th minute, but the Atletico defense proved resolute (11:22).

Antoine Griezmann provided a moment of individual brilliance for the home side when he tried to dribble past an opposing player but was subsequently thwarted (12:43). Sadly, for Atletico, the moment didn’t translate to a sustained attacking threat. Barcelona were then awarded a free-kick following a clumsy challenge by Gabi (13:03), but nothing came from it as Atlético Madrid’s defense held firm.

In the 14th minute, Barcelona had their first significant chance. A defence-splitting pass found Ivan Rakitic, but his shot destined for the top right corner was superbly saved by Jan Oblak. That save was easily the best of the match up until that point (14:11).

On the other end, Fernando Torres of Atletico tried his luck with a promising shot from a distance at 16:40, but it ballooned inches over the crossbar (16:50). Subsequently, Oliver Torres saw yellow for bringing down an opponent (17:40), reflecting the competitive nature of the match.

Juanfran continuously tried to create chances for Atletico but was repeatedly penalized for tactical fouls, including shirt pulling in the 21st minute, leading to a free-kick for Barcelona (20:48). Endeavours from Jordi Alba and Luis Suarez to find the back of the net met stiff resistance, showing the hardiness at the back for Atletico.

Around the 24th minute, Barcelona came very close to taking the lead. Luis Suarez, meeting a corner kick, unleashed a shot that smashed against the bar (24:08). Shortly after, Barcelona’s Thomas Vermaelen sustained an injury and had to be substituted for Jeremy Mathieu (27:28).

So far, neither side could break the deadlock despite intense efforts. As a result of constant midfield skirmishes and frequent throw-ins, the game somewhat stagnated. 

The first significant break in the monotony came as Andres Iniesta received a yellow card for a tough tackle on Filipe Luis, who himself had been booked earlier (43:49, 42:31). Minutes later, Koke sent a cross into the Barcelona box, but Ter Stegen was alert enough to gather the ball safely (44:26).

At halftime, the referee brought a halt to the first 45 minutes. It wasn't the most thrilling half, but a chess match where Barcelona’s ball retention tactics and Atletico’s counter-attacking maneuvres showcased their respective game plans.

The second half commenced with Atletico Madrid kicking off (00:00). They started brightly, and Oliver Torres dragged a promising shot narrowly wide of the right post within the first minute (00:28).

Five minutes into the half, Fernando Torres capitalized on a neat pass from Tiago to send in a low drive that banked in off the left post and ignited the home crowd with an opening goal (05:59).

Barcelona didn’t take long to retaliate. An ugly tackle by Antoine Griezmann handed them a free kick in a very promising position (08:15). Neymar stepped up and impeccably curled the ball into the top left corner to level matters at 1-1 with an absolutely phenomenal strike (09:46).

Following the equalizer, the game resumed its pattern of strategic play. Andres Iniesta whipped crosses into the box, Jan Oblak thwarted uncountable efforts (11:22), and Fernando Torres was unfortunately subbed off after an injury forced him off the field to be replaced by Jackson Martinez (16:14).

The Barcelona offensive machine clicked into gear midway through the second half. The game-changing moment came as Lionel Messi played a neat one-two with Luis Suarez before the latter set him up inside the box to score Barcelona’s second goal, placing it effectively in the bottom right corner (31:26).

Fatigue started to become a factor as players of both teams committed more fouls. Yannick Carrasco attempted an ambitious long-range strike but was denied by Ter Stegen (23:23). The last substitutes entered with Atletico putting Luciano Vietto on for Gabi and Barcelona with Rafinha taking the corner responsibilities (35:12, 41:40).

As the game approached its end, Barcelona maintained control, with Neymar demonstrating his technical abilities at every opportunity. The crowd attendance was officially registered at 53,491, a testament to the draw of these two footballing powerhouses (37:06).

In terms of defending, both sides had standout performances. Jackson Martinez found himself unmarked but only managed a tame shot straight at Ter Stegen (38:12). Lionel Messi had another opportunity from a free-kick towards the end but sent his effort high over the bar (44:15).

Ultimately, Barcelona held on to their lead despite the home side trying to break Barcelona's defensive lines. The final minutes saw Atletico try to push forward but to no avail, as time was not on their side. The referee, after checking his watch, finally blew the whistle to signal the end of an engaging, albeit at times scrappy, football match (47:11).

In summation, this match was defined by tactical play with Barcelona’s possession dominance eventually prevailing over Atletico’s staunch defense and counter-attacks. Luis Enrique’s side walked away with a crucial three points, continuing their push in the La Liga title race. Despite the defeat, Atletico Madrid showed character and fighting spirit that promises an exciting remainder to their season. The crucial takeaways were Neymar and Messi’s clinical finishing, and Atletico’s need for more cutting-edge, finishing their considerable efforts in front of goal.
